Federal Court
Pinard, J.
March 17, 2005.
Counsel:
Michael Goldstein, for the applicants;
Simone Truong, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Michael Goldstein, Montreal, Quebec, for the applicants;
John H. Sims, Q.C., Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
Pinard, J.
: This is an application for judicial review of a decision of the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board (the "Board") dated October 21, 2003, wherein the Board found the applicants not to be Convention refugees or "people in need of protection" as defined in sections 96 and 97 respectively of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27.

[2]
Argery Mendoza Castillo (the principal applicant), Gerardo Elfidio Naranjo Ocampo and Brandon Steven Mendoza Castillo are citizens of Costa Rica. They allege a well-founded fear of persecution by reasons of death threats made against them by Manuel Castillo, the individual accused of raping the principal applicant's sister, who was mentally challenged, in September 1995.

[3]
Following this rape, the applicant's sister got pregnant and gave birth to a boy on May 31, 1996. This child's name is Brandon Steven Mendoza Castillo and is one of the applicants in the present case. He is in the legal custody of the two other applicants, but has not been adopted by them. An arrest warrant was issued on January 17, 1997, for the arrest of the rapist, however he was never found.

[4]
The Board based its decision on a negative credibility finding. In that regard, this Court cannot substitute its opinion for that of the Board unless the applicant can demonstrate that the Board's decision was based on an erroneous finding of fact that it made in a capricious manner or without regard for the material before it (subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Courts Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. F-7). The Board is a specialized tribunal capable of assessing the plausibility and credibility of a testimony, to the extent that the inferences which it draws from it are not unreasonable ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.A.)) and its reasons are expressed clearly and comprehensibly ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.A.)).

[5]
In the case at bar, the Board specifically took into account the applicant's behaviour at the hearing. The transcript confirms to a certain extent the Board's impressions that the applicant's testimony was laborious and hesitant. This Court is in no position to review further those aspects which go to the applicant's demeanour, which the Board is uniquely positioned to assess ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (QL) (T.D.)).

[6]
The Board may prefer documentary evidence from various sources to the testimony of a refugee claimant ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (QL) (C.A.)) and may choose the documentary evidence it prefers ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (QL) (T.D.)). It was well within the purview of the Board to not give any probative value to the document from the "Patronato Nacional de la Infancia", the document that the applicant obtained which would have allowed her to take Brandon out of the country. The Board did not receive any satisfactory explanation on how the applicant's sister, who according to other documents is mentally ill and could not even do basic additions, could sign such a document. This conclusion is not unreasonable.

[7]
The reason the applicant claims that they did not complete the adoption procedure was because they were afraid for their lives and had to leave the country, yet they made no complaint to the police following the second threatening phone call by Manuel. Regardless of whether they thought the police could do nothing, if they were truly fearful they would have attempted to obtain protection from the State. It was not unreasonable for the Board to draw a negative inference from the applicants' lack of diligence in pursuing the complaint.

[8]
Furthermore, when questioned as to whether he had any siblings, Brandon answered yes, yet could not remember their names since he had not seen them in a long time. The applicant's explanation for Brandon's answer was that Brandon was Christian and was therefore told that everyone is his brother and sister. The Board found this explanation unsatisfactory. It was not unreasonable for the Board to doubt this explanation as it brings into question the relationship between Brandon and the two other applicants.

[9]
It is understandable that the applicant could have been nervous while testifying, and hesitant in answering some questions, however, the content of her testimony is not corroborated by the evidence presented in its support. There were far too many inconsistencies for the applicant's story to be credible and it is my view that the Board did not err in finding as it did.

[10]
For all the above reasons, the intervention of this Court is not warranted and the application for judicial review is dismissed.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27, sections 96 and 97
Federal Courts Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. F-7, subsection 18.1(4)
legal_issues: The standard of review applicable to decisions of a specialized administrative tribunal regarding credibility assessments.
The permissible scope of a court's review of an administrative tribunal's factual findings.
Whether a failure to report threats to law enforcement can be considered in assessing credibility in a claim for protection.
The weight to be given to demeanour evidence in assessing the credibility of a claimant.
The evidentiary value of documentary evidence versus testimonial evidence in determining a claim.
The reasonableness of an administrative tribunal's inferences drawn from inconsistencies in testimony.
The requirements for establishing a well-founded fear of persecution.
The legal consequences of inconsistencies in testimony regarding familial relationships.
factual_background: Three Costa Rican citizens applied for refugee status in Canada.
The applicants allege they experienced a well-founded fear of persecution due to death threats from Manuel Castillo.
The death threats relate to a 1995 rape of the principal applicant's sister, who had a mental disability.
The sister became pregnant as a result of the rape and gave birth to a son, Brandon Steven Mendoza Castillo, who is also an applicant.
Brandon is in the legal custody of the other two applicants but has not been formally adopted.
An arrest warrant was issued for Manuel Castillo in 1997, but he was not apprehended.
The applicants claim they did not complete adoption procedures due to fear for their safety and the need to leave the country.
The applicants reported receiving threatening phone calls from Manuel Castillo.
During questioning, Brandon stated he had siblings but could not recall their names.
The applicants provided a document from the "Patronato Nacional de la Infancia" intended to facilitate Brandon's departure from the country.
The Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board denied the applicants' claim for refugee status and protection.

Applicants: They fear persecution in Costa Rica due to death threats from Manuel Castillo, the accused rapist of the principal applicant's sister.
The threats were made because Manuel Castillo raped the principal applicant's sister, who was mentally challenged, resulting in the birth of Brandon Steven Mendoza Castillo.
They obtained a document from the “Patronato Nacional de la Infancia” to allow Brandon to leave the country.
They did not complete the adoption procedure for Brandon because they feared for their lives and had to leave the country.
Brandon's inability to recall his siblings' names was due to his Christian upbringing, where everyone is considered a brother or sister.
Respondents: The applicants' testimony was laborious and hesitant, indicating a lack of credibility.
The document from the “Patronato Nacional de la Infancia” is suspect because the applicant's sister, who is mentally ill, purportedly signed it.
The applicants did not report the second threatening phone call to the police, despite claiming to fear for their lives, demonstrating a lack of diligence in seeking state protection.
Brandon's inability to remember his siblings' names, and the explanation provided, cast doubt on the relationship between Brandon and the other applicants.
The applicant's testimony is inconsistent and lacks corroborating evidence.

court_analysis: The court upheld the Refugee Protection Division’s (the Board) negative credibility finding, deferring to the Board’s expertise in assessing witness testimony and demeanor. The court explicitly stated it would not substitute its own opinion for the Board’s unless the decision was made capriciously or without regard to the evidence (subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Courts Act).

The court found the Board’s assessment of the applicant’s testimony as ‘laborious and hesitant’ was within its purview, as assessing demeanor is a specialized function of the Board. The court declined to further review these aspects.

The court reasoned that the Board was justified in giving little weight to a document from the “Patronato Nacional de la Infancia” because the applicant failed to adequately explain how her mentally ill sister could have signed it. This was deemed a reasonable conclusion, not an error in law.

The court agreed with the Board’s negative inference drawn from the applicants’ failure to report death threats to the police. While acknowledging the applicants’ claim of fear, the court reasoned that a genuine fear for one’s life would logically lead to seeking state protection, and the lack of a police complaint undermined their credibility.

The court found the Board’s rejection of the applicant’s explanation for Brandon’s statement about having siblings (attributing it to his Christian upbringing) to be reasonable. The court agreed that the explanation was unsatisfactory and cast doubt on the relationship between Brandon and the other applicants.

The court concluded that the inconsistencies within the applicant’s testimony, combined with the lack of corroborating evidence, justified the Board’s overall negative credibility assessment. The court found the Board did not err in its decision.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is dismissed.
